data.title: Using Computer Vision to Extract Document Structure
data.description: This is a guest post written by Frederik Brammer, a student in Germany. Due to the Coronavirus pandemic, working from home has become more important than ever. Because of homeschooling, school servers have crashed due to the enormous amount of traffic – in some cases, multiple days go by without contact

data.title: How to Use Roboflow with IBM Visual Recognition (IBM Watson vs Roboflow)
data.description: IBM recently announced they are shutting down IBM Visual Inspection, their product for creating custom computer vision models for classification and object detection. No new instances can be created and all current instances will be fully shutdown in December 2021. This has left many looking for IBM Visual Inspection alternatives.

data.title: Top 5 Ways Manufacturers Are Already Using Computer Vision
data.description: Computer vision has become essential to building strong and stable manufacturing processes for operations of all sizes, and manufacturers across every industry are using the technology to boost the productivity and quality of their production lines. data.title: Roboflow Changelog: April 2021
data.description: Each month we bring you the high level bullet-points of improvements and additions to Roboflow. If you missed it, last month's changelog is here. data.title: Using Your Webcam with Roboflow Models
data.description: Computer vision models are normally trained to give you predictions on a single image at a time. The input to these models are often individual photos or frames from recorded videos collected asynchronously. But oftentimes you'll want to get predictions from a camera feed in realtime. data.title: Zero-Shot Content Moderation with OpenAI's New CLIP Model
data.description: OpenAI's CLIP model can "zero-shot" understand an image's semantic meaning. We walk through how we use CLIP to moderate content for our game paint.wtf.

data.title: Andrew Ng: "Deploying to production means you're halfway there."
data.description: Andrew Ng, the co-founder of Google Brain and Coursera and former Chief Scientist at Baidu, spoke at this week's Scale Transform conference on the transition from "big data" to "good data." data.title: Video Inference with Roboflow
data.description: One common question we get is "Can I use my Roboflow model on a video?" The answer is yes! Videos are really just a sequence of images, so your model can give predictions just like it does on images. The process is simple: 1) split your video into frames, 2)

data.title: Danger Monitoring for Cyclists using Raspberry Pi and Object Detection
data.description: My solution is a low-cost prototype danger monitoring application on Raspberry Pi that detects cars and bicycles, then warns the cyclist with an LED light.

data.title: What is Embedded Machine Learning?
data.description: Machine learning – the software discipline of mapping inputs to outputs without explicitly programmed relationships – requires substantial computational resources. Traditionally, this limits where machine learning models can run to very powerful supercomputers. But this is changing.  Computation is required at two core moments in the machine learning development lifecycle: model training

data.title: Using Computer Vision to Detect Personal Protective Equipment
data.description: From 2018 to 2019, construction injuries rose 61% with over 5,000 workers dying on the job. I built a computer vision application to detect proper PPE.

data.title: How We Built Paint.wtf, an AI Game with 150,000+ Submissions that Judges Your Art
data.description: Paint.wtf is an online game that uses AI to score user-submitted digital drawings to zany prompts like, "Draw a giraffe in the arctic" or "Draw a bumblebee loves capitalism." It's Cards Against Humanity meets Microsoft Paint. The quality and quantity of submissions on paint.wtf really impressed us.Paint.

data.title: Introducing Roboflow Support for NVIDIA Jetson
data.description: Deploy Models to NVIDIA Embedded Devices Deploying models to the edge offers unique benefits: inference speeds can be increased, the model can run offline, and data can be processed locally. data.title: ELI5 CLIP: A Beginner's Guide to the CLIP Model
data.description: I'll break OpenAI's CLIP model down for you in an accessible and fun read! In this post, I'll cover what CLIP is, how CLIP works, and applications of CLIP.

data.title: 5 Emerging Trends in Computer Vision Applications from OpenCV's AI Competition
data.description: After reviewing submissions from the OpenCV AI competition, I noticed themes in how people are innovating with computer vision. I share 5 emerging trends.

data.title: Running Tensorflow JS on an NVIDIA Jetson
data.description: The NVIDIA Jetson line is a series of AI-capable low-power computers. They range from the $59 Jetson Nano (2GB) to the $899 Jetson AGX Xavier and are a popular choice for powering machine learning projects on the edge. data.description: OpenCV has been a key part of advancing computer vision capabilities for developers for over 20 years. data.title: How to Use Roboflow and Streamlit to Visualize Object Detection Output
data.description: Follow this "how to" guide to build your own computer vision object detection model and deployed app with Roboflow and Streamlit.

data.title: Using Computer Vision to Improve Disability Access in Music Education
data.description: This is a guest post by Mehek Gosalia, a high school student from Sammamish, Washington. She plans to study computer science. data.title: Liquid Neural Networks in Computer Vision
data.description: Excitement is building in the artificial intelligence community around MIT's recent release of liquid neural networks. The breakthroughs that Hasani and team have made are incredible. In this post, we will discuss the new liquid neural networks and what they might mean for the vision field.

data.title: How to Train and Deploy a License Plate Detector to the Luxonis OAK
data.description: In this post, we will leverage Roboflow and the Luxonis OAK to train and deploy a custom license plate model to your OAK device.

data.title: Using Computer Vision to Make Card Grading Faster and Cheaper
data.description: James Nitsch used Roboflow to organize his images and build models, enabling him to quickly assess quality and whether the card should be officially graded.
